docs.lead_paragraph: The shares of Access Health Inc. rose 18 percent yesterday after the company said it would provide health information services to one million Florida Blue Cross and Blue Shield members in the next 15 months. Access Health shares rose $7.6875, to $50.50, in Nasdaq trading. Access Health, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., gives customers access to a broad range of health information and counseling services through the phone, the Internet, fax, printed materials or cable television.

headline.main: ACCESS HEALTH SHARES CLIMB ON EXPANSION OF SERVICES

docs.abstract: Shares of Access Health Inc rise 18 percent after company says it will provide health information services to one million Florida Blue Cross and Blue Shield members in next 15 months; Access Health shares rise $7.6875, to $50.50 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prodded for weeks by the Dole campaign to make public President Clinton's medical records, the White House tonight released an 11-page sheaf of doctors' statements about the President's medical history. The packet -- distributed hours after evening television newscasts and many newspaper deadlines -- included a four-page statement by Dr. E. Connie Mariano, the senior White House physician, summarizing Mr. Clinton's medical history and results of laboratory tests. The medical records and laboratory reports themselves were not made public.

headline.main: More Information Released On the President's Health

docs.abstract: White House releases 11-page sheaf of doctors' statements about Pres Clinton's medical history; Dole campaign has said for weeks that Clinton's medical records should be made public, as Bob Dole's were; White House spokesman, Michael D McCurry, says information that was released on Clinton's health now exceeds what was released about Dole's health (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: By early yesterday afternoon, the bronze-and-silver statue of the patron saint of Naples was already festooned with dollar bills, his right hand raised as if to bless the start of New York City's oldest and grandest street fair, the Feast of San Gennaro. Lucy Spata, a green apron over her black dress, sliced the end off a curlicue of sausage and dropped it onto a hero roll, the same way her grandmother did at the feast in the 1920's. ''That'll be four dollars, doll,'' Ms. Spata said as she put the huge sandwich into waiting hands.

headline.main: Feast of San Gennaro Returns, a Lot Saintlier, Officials Say

docs.abstract: Feast of San Gennaro opens on Mulberry Street in Little Italy, NYC, first year under new management after City Hall crackdown intended to rid street festival of corruption and mob influence; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following the Prudential Insurance Company's loss of a roughly $4 billion health insurance contract, Prudential executives and industry analysts said yesterday that they expected a major restructuring of the 120-year-old company's health care business. The restructuring, the analysts said, would likely mean selling some parts of the business, as well as buying competing insurers, in an effort to dominate the market in some regions of the country.

headline.main: With Loss of A.A.R.P. Work, Many Think Prudential Will Be Reshaped

docs.abstract: Prudential Insurance executives and industry analysts say that they expect major restructuring of Prudential Insurance Co in view of loss of $4 billion contract health insurance contract; United Healthcare Corp outbid Prudential to win business of American Assn of Retired Persons; analysts say restructuring would likely mean selling some parts of the business, as well as buying competing insurers, in an effort to dominate the market in some regions of the country (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Advance Strongly On Producer-Prices Report Stocks rose as the Producer Price Index showed scant signs of inflation amid surprisingly strong economic growth and corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 17.02 points, at 5,771.94, within 7 points of its closing high set on May 22. Broader indexes remained short of their records. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 3.85 points, to 671.13, or 1.1 percent short of its closing high. The Nasdaq index climbed 11.86 points, to 1,165.81, roughly 6.7 percent below its acme. $(Page D6.$) Hefty increases for food and energy drove up producer prices three-tenths of 1 percent in August, but a slip in the rest of the Producer Price Index for finished goods was said to show that inflation was not a threat. $(D4.$) S.E.C. Settles With Tudor Tudor Investment, headed by the trader Paul Tudor Jones 2d, agreed to pay $800,000 in fines after the S.E.C. uncovered trades that could be construed as attempts to manipulate the market. Tudor settled the case without admitting or denying the charges. $(D5.$) Revamping Ahead for Prudential? Analysts said Prudential Insurance could restructure its health care business following the loss of a $4 billion A.A.R.P. contract. $(D6.$) A Vote of Confidence in Salomon Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren Buffett, said it planned to convert 140,000 preferred shares into common stock of Salomon Inc. this year. The move shows Mr. Buffett is warming to Salomon, which has seen its fortunes improve after a hard 1995. $(D2.$) Doubletree to Buy Red Lion Hotels Doubletree said it would acquire Red Lion Hotels for about $1 billion. Two-thirds of Red Lion's shares are held by a limited partnership involving Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. $(D4.$) A Deal Undone Shakes Wall Street Xerox has long sought to be judged only as a document-processing company and finally found a buyer this year for its poorly performing insurance units. And that goes a long way to explain Wall Street's initial panic after an announcement Wednesday that the deal had fallen apart. Market Place. $(D6.$) ABC to Broadcast 'The Lion King' The ABC television network, which is owned by Walt Disney, said it would broadcast Disney's wildly successful movie ''The Lion King'' in November, the first such broadcast of a modern-era Disney animated feature film. ABC also said that Spike Lee would develop a new comedy for the network, in association with Brandon Tartikoff, a former head of entertainment programming for NBC. $(D2.$) A New Marketing Course for G.M. General Motors' new marketing strategy starts with its 1997 models. First up is Buick, where campaigns attach slogans to certain models, rather than use an overarching tag line for the division. Advertising. $(D2.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to head off rapidly growing competition from banks and technology companies, the New England Life Insurance Company has bought a substantial stake in a company that produces computer software for managing personal finance, company officials plan to announce today. The purchase of a one-sixth share in Meca Software -- which produces software that permits a range of electronic transactions, from writing checks to managing investment portfolios and buying insurance -- will make New England Life a partner with five banks including BankAmerica and Nationsbank.

headline.main: New England Life to Announce Stake in Meca Software

docs.abstract: New England Life Insurance Co buys one-sixth share in Meca Software for approximately $10 million; company produces computer software for managing personal finance; deal is latest development in growing struggle for market share in huge financial services sector among insurance, banking and investment companies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Shift in Standard For Environmental Rules The Clinton Administration said that it would start basing all environmental protection standards on the particular risks that pollution poses to children's health. The change could lead to tougher rules on everything from soot fouling the air to microbes contaminating water. $(Page A14.$) Xerox Insurance Sale Is Canceled Xerox and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said that they were calling off the planned $2.7 billion sale of Xerox's insurance units to Kohlberg. Neither company would say why the sale, for which Xerox had already taken a $1.5 billion charge, was canceled. $(D5.$) Motorola Warns Of Weak Profit Motorola's stock fell after the company warned Wall Street that disappointing sales of cellular phones and other products were taking a much bigger toll on its earnings than analysts had been projecting for the current quarter. $(D2.$) Blow to Overseas Lending Agency The House rejected a bill to renew the lending and insuring authority of the agency that provides insurance and loan guarantees to companies investing in poor nations. $(D2.$) Nasdaq Is Said to Cost More Two studies argue that institutional investors pay higher costs to trade on Nasdaq than they do on stock exchanges. $(D6.$) New England Life in Software Deal New England Life Insurance has bought a substantial stake in Meca Software, which produces personal-finance software. $(D3.$) New Chief at Perot Systems Morton Meyerson, Ross Perot's business lieutenant since the 1970's, stepped aside as chief executive of the Perot Systems Corporation and promoted the company president to take his place. $(D16.$) Don't Raise Rates, Some Say With unemployment falling to just 5.1 percent and economic growth robust, it appears that interest rates will be raised. Still, some economists are urging American monetary-policy makers to let the good times roll. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. $(A1.$) F.T.C. Approval for Time Warner The F.T.C. plans to announce that it has officially approved Time Warner's $6.5 billion merger with Turner Broadcasting. $(D17.$) New Tack in Mobile-Home Bid Sun Communities, one of the three mobile-home park operators wooing shareholders of Chateau Properties, said it was willing to offer cash. Its original offer was in stock. $(D4.$) Net Gatekeeper May Sell Stock The private company that the Government put in charge of registering Internet names has been exploring the idea of cashing in on its gatekeeping role by selling stock. $(A1.$) Brooklyn Union to Cut Some Rates Brooklyn Union Gas said it would lower its gas rates next year for many customers and then freeze them over the next five years, the first time a large utility has committed itself to a cap on rates for such a long period. $(B3.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Planned Parenthood Federation of America announced yesterday that it would give some women seeking early abortions the option of taking medication to induce abortion as part of a clinical trial approved by the Food and Drug Administration. About 35 federation affiliates are expected to test two drugs, methotrexate and misoprostol, for abortions in women no more than 49 days pregnant. The program is to start accepting patients in a few weeks.

headline.main: Planned Parenthood to Participate in a Test of Abortion Drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: Miami's longtime city manager was charged today with conspiring to steal public money in a Federal corruption case that also snared a city commissioner and a lobbyist. The criminal complaint against the city manager, Cesar Odio, Miami's chief executive and administrator since 1985, charges him and the lobbyist, Jorge L. de Cardenas, with conspiring to siphon off $12,500 a month from a city contract with an insurance company that provided health coverage to city employees.

headline.main: U.S. Accuses 2 Miami Officials of Corruption

docs.abstract: Cesar Odio, Miami's longtime city manager, is charged today with conspiring to steal public money in Federal corruption case; is charged with lobbyist Jorge L de Cardenas with conspiring to siphon off $12,500 per month from city contract with insurance company that provided health coverage to city employees; Miller Dawkins, elected member of city's five-member commission since 1981, is charged with seeking bribes from computer company that had contracts with city; Odio declares innocence; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks rose yesterday as heightened tensions in the Middle East drove up the price of crude oil and the shares of oil companies like Exxon and Texaco. The Dow Jones industrial average, up as much as 43 points during the day and within 11 points of its closing high, closed at 5,754.92, up 27.74 points. The Dow, which includes four oil-related companies among its 30 blue-chip issues, is up 12.5 percent this year, a far stronger gain than the 8.4 percent increase on the broader-based Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

headline.main: Dow Up 27.74 Points, Aided by Oil Stocks

docs.abstract: Stocks rise as heightened tensions in Middle East drive up prices of crude oil; Dow Jones industrial average closes at 5,754.92, up 27.74 points; Dow, which includes four oil-related companies, is up 12.5 percent this year, while broader-based Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 8.4 percent (M)
